@metadata.goal: The student can identify and maintain the whole when working with fractions

steps.dialogue: Maya partitioned her whole bookmark into equal parts and shaded some purple. Count all the parts to find how many make up one whole.

prompt.text: How many equal parts make up the whole bar?

step.dialogue: Count all the equal parts in the whole bar, not just the shaded ones.

events.name: pulse_all_sections
events.description: All six sections of the bar pulse sequentially from top to bottom to emphasize counting all parts

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_all_sections]Let's think about this together. The whole bar includes both the shaded and unshaded parts. Count every section from top to bottom.

events.name: overlay_counting
events.description: Animated counting overlay appears on each section sequentially, displaying numbers 1 through 6 as each part is counted from top to bottom

events.name: bracket_whole
events.description: A bracket appears along the side of the entire bar with label 'whole = 6 parts' to show all sections together form the whole

step.dialogue: [event:overlay_counting][event:bracket_whole]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. The whole bookmark has all these parts - let me count them with you: one, two, three, four, five, six. Even though only two parts are shaded purple, the whole bar is made of 6 equal parts. That's how we identify the whole in fractions.

on_correct.dialogue: You counted all the parts that make up the whole.
